周六，大约10万人参加了在伦敦市中心举行的亲巴勒斯坦示威活动，他们在英国首都游行，要求在两周前哈马斯袭击以色列后立即在加沙停火。

抗议者高呼“自由巴勒斯坦”，高举横幅，挥舞巴勒斯坦国旗，穿过伦敦，然后在英国首相里希·苏纳克的官邸和办公室唐宁街集结。

警方估计有 10 万人参加了巴勒斯坦团结运动组织的“巴勒斯坦全国游行”示威活动。

一名妇女表示：“作为一名希望有一天能回家的巴勒斯坦人，作为一名在加沙有兄弟姐妹和家人的巴勒斯坦人，我希望我们能做更多，但抗议是我们目前能做的。”拒绝透露她的名字，告诉路透社。

许多口号和横幅都包含强烈的反以色列口号，一名抗议者举着印有苏纳克、美国总统乔·拜登和以色列总理本雅明·内塔尼亚胡照片的横幅，上面写着“因战争罪通缉”。

警方在游行前警告说，任何支持被英国列为恐怖组织的哈马斯的人都将面临逮捕，任何仇恨犯罪事件都不会被容忍。

抗议活动似乎是和平的，没有立即报告有人被捕。

周五的数据显示，与去年同期相比，本月反犹太主义犯罪增加了 1,353%，而仇视伊斯兰教的犯罪增加了 140%。

英国外交大臣詹姆斯·克莱维利在开罗举行的和平峰会上表示：“这是一个长期以来激发人们热情的问题，我们现在都在社交媒体和我们的社区中看到，当前局势已变得多么分裂和两极分化。”

英国外交大臣詹姆斯·克莱维利周六表示，他已与以色列政府谈及以色列政府有义务尊重国际法并保护加沙平民的生命，并要求以色列军队表现出克制。

克莱弗利在埃及主办的开罗和平峰会上表示：“英国明确表示，并且一直明确表示，以色列有权自卫，并有权确保释放 10 月 7 日被绑架的人。”

“我们也清楚，我们必须努力，他们也必须努力减轻加沙巴勒斯坦人民的痛苦，他们的行动符合国际法。

他补充说：“尽管情况极其困难，但我仍呼吁以色列军队保持纪律、专业精神和克制。”

克莱弗利表示，国际社会需要努力防止加沙局势引发地区冲突，并称这正是哈马斯所希望的。

克莱弗利说：“我们有责任、有责任共同努力，防止不稳定局势席卷该地区，并夺走更多人的生命。”

“因此，我们必须确保哈马斯不会获胜。相反，我们必须确保和平共处获胜。”

迈克尔·霍尔登报道；托比·乔普拉编辑; Sat, 21 Oct 2023 14:24:39 GMT EETIV6LA3JN3HO7R5SWKI6E3YE https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/uk-foreign-minister-cleverly-calls-restraint-israeli-military-2023-10-21/Reuters以色列巴勒斯坦/埃及外交英国（更新 1 1） Italy's Meloni urges international community not to fall into Hamas "trap"

意大利总理乔治亚·梅洛尼周六表示，国际社会必须避免以色列和哈马斯之间的战争升级，并制定两国解决方案的路线图。

梅洛尼是在埃及开罗中东和平国际峰会上发表上述讲话时发表上述言论的。哈马斯袭击造成 1,400 人死亡，以色列准备对加沙发动地面攻击。

梅洛尼用意大利语说：“尽管我们的出发点相距甚远，但我们的利益完全重叠：加沙正在发生的事情不会演变成一场更广泛的冲突、宗教战争或文明冲突。”

“我的印象是，这是哈马斯袭击的真正目的，不是为了捍卫巴勒斯坦人民的权利，而是一次将在巴勒斯坦人和以色列人之间造成不可逾越的鸿沟的袭击，这意味着目标是我们所有人，我们不能落入这个陷阱，那是非常愚蠢的。”

意大利总理在开罗会见了巴勒斯坦总统马哈茂德·阿巴斯，然后前往特拉维夫会见以色列总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡。

这位意大利领导人告诉记者，梅洛尼和阿巴斯讨论了努力降低以色列与哈马斯战争升级和两国解决方案的必要性，他指的是建立两个独立国家的想法，一个是以色列人的国家，一个是以色列人的国家。一个是针对巴勒斯坦人的。

梅洛尼说：“我希望整个国际社会都有责任，在我看来，有责任加快这一进程，为冲突提供结构性解决方案。”

她强调两国解决方案必须有明确的时间表。

吉塞尔达·瓦尼奥尼报道；托马斯·雅诺夫斯基和艾莉森·威廉姆斯编辑; Sat, 21 Oct 2023 14:23:39 GMT PONS4ZJQDJOO3AWTCYVGATKOX4 https://www.reuters.com/world/middle-east/italys-meloni-urges-international-community-not-fall-into-hamas-trap-2023-10-21/Reuters以色列巴勒斯坦/埃及外交MELONI（更新 1，PIX） In Argentina's icy south, a political dynasty fades and a new power rises

艾丽西娅·基什内尔 (Alicia Kirchner) 是阿根廷最强大的政治王朝的一位元老，她满怀热情地回忆起自己在里奥加耶戈斯 (Rio Gallegos) 帮助修建房屋、学校和第一家医院的情景。里奥加耶戈斯是该国多风的巴塔哥尼亚南部的一座小城市。

基什内尔家族包括阿根廷最后四任总统中的两位，他们在寒冷的南部圣克鲁斯省统治了数十年，他们称之为家乡，在那里拥有土地、投资和酒店。

那个王朝——强大的庇​​隆主义运动的左翼核心——现在正在走向衰落，这是该国政治权力动态的结构性转变，极右翼局外人哈维尔·米莱(Javier Milei)的形式出现了一股新力量。

想要“锯断”政治现状的米莱在8月份的公开初选中取得了令人震惊的胜利，包括在圣克鲁斯获得了最大的选票份额，成为周日赢得第一轮大选的热门人选。

这位自由主义经济学家掀起了选民对今年通胀率将达到200%的愤怒浪潮，以及二十年来最严重的经济危机，导致五分之二的人口陷入贫困。许多人指责该国最近的统治者。

“米雷是不满的产物，”77 岁的即将卸任的圣克鲁斯州长基什内尔在她的官邸对路透社表示，该官邸距离她已故的兄弟、前总统内斯特·基什内尔（2003-2007 年）的陵墓不远。

“最让我担心的是人们没有希望，”她说。

她的嫂子克里斯蒂娜·费尔南德斯·德基什内尔 (Cristina Fernandez de Kirchner) 于 2007 年至 2015 年担任总统，直到最近，她还是阿根廷政坛无可争议的明星。费尔南德斯·德基什内尔 (Fernandez de Kirchner) 于 2019 年亲自挑选了现任总统阿尔贝托·费尔南德斯 (Alberto Fernandez)，并继续担任副总统。

但政治风向正在发生变化。 70 岁的费尔南德斯·德基什内尔 (Fernandez de Kirchner) 是一位颇具争议的人物，曾与投资者发生冲突，但却是拉丁美洲左派的偶像。如今，他正在退出聚光灯，数十年来首次不再竞选公职。

在圣克鲁斯，米莱在初选中赢得了29%的选票，远远领先于执政的庇隆主义联盟和保守派候选人帕特里夏·布尔里奇。庇隆主义者自己也看到了基什内尔家族内部的强大转变，执政党现在支持中间派经济部长塞尔吉奥·马萨。

“我们这里都很穷”

圣克鲁斯是该国正在发生的大规模政治动荡的一个缩影，这可能会扰乱市场，影响阿根廷与中国和巴西等贸易伙伴的关系，并抵消在妇女权利和堕胎方面取得的进步。

阿根廷是世界最大的大豆和玉米出口国之一，也是国际货币基金组织 (IMF) 的最大债务国，拥有 440 亿美元的计划，并一直在吸引对其巨大的页岩气和电池金属锂资源的投资。

但多年的经济低迷、债务和货币危机损害了圣克鲁斯等当地经济，自 2018 年以来，该地区的贫困率增加了一倍多，达到约 40%，该州雇用了一半以上的劳动力，但工资却远远落后于通货膨胀。

“我们这里都很穷，”23 岁的布莱恩·佛朗哥 (Brian Franco) 说，他是旅游小镇埃尔卡拉法特 (El Calafate) 的一名兼职司机，除了修理洗衣机维持生计之外，他还负责接送游客前往著名的佩里托·莫雷诺 (Perito Moreno) 冰川。

这个偏远小镇也是基什内尔家族拥有的埃尔卡拉法特酒店涉嫌贪污和洗钱计划的发生地。去年，在另一起腐败案件中，费尔南德斯·德基什内尔被判处六年监禁，这使她无法担任未来的公职，尽管这面临着漫长的上诉程序。

在安第斯山脉的阴影下，度假村周围随处可见基什内尔家族的标志，街道标志上刻着他们的名字，橙色是他们选出的市长竞选时所采用的橙色颜色，自 2007 年以来，基什内尔家族一直不间断地执政。

但现在，紫色气球和黄色旗帜——米雷竞选的颜色——装饰着这片偏远飞地的一些房屋。

“我认识的人中有一半都投票给米莱，”佛朗哥在一家理发店外聚集的一群年轻人中说道。有些人为了周末修剪而步行了四五公里（两三英里），并表示当地的公共交通基本上不存在。

当地人和官员表示，人们的购买力已经崩溃。与此同时，建筑材料价格飙升，导致当地建设放缓。

即将离任的左翼地区副省长尤金尼奥·基罗加(Eugenio Quiroga)表示，“街上没有钱流通”，因为“人们的工资只够维持基本生活，这损害了当地企业”，并最终损害了公众对政府的支持。

在埃尔卡拉法特，建筑师沃尔特·皮耶罗尼 (Walter Pieroni) 表示，由于规划不善，主要商业中心边缘的一些房产可能会几天没有水。房屋也未完工，业主无力承担在国家曾经交给他们的土地上建造的材料。

“自八月份以来，我的实得工资减少了一半。好几个星期都没有建筑材料到达。供应商不会向我出售产品，因为他们不知道要收取什么价格，”皮罗尼说。 “每个人都很累，这就是为什么米莱被接受，即使他很极端。”

“我投票支持变革”

10 月的一个早晨，黎明时分，58 岁的吉列尔莫·卡内瓦莱 (Guillermo Carnevale) 在巴塔哥尼亚的风和早晨的寒冷中弓着背，打开了自己的小五金店。

Carnevale 在长期的新冠肺炎 (COVID-19) 封锁期间失去了经营当地一家加油站的工作，他开设了一家销售钉子、螺丝和工具的商店，这已成为他家人的生命线。鉴于投入价格上涨和 133% 的利率阻碍了信贷获取，他仍然面临挑战。

四年前，他在选举中支持佩隆尼斯特·费尔南德斯，并在 2015 年支持主流保守派毛里西奥·马克里。但现在他已经皈依了米雷，甚至于周日作为自由主义市长候选人竞选里约加耶戈斯市的市长。

“几乎没有任何工作……所以人们开始公开反对灾难性的经济形势，这构成了我们自由主义政党的基础，”他说。

除了严峻的经济影响之外，当他的儿子告诉他他想搬到西班牙或德国过上更好的生活时，真正的转折点到来了。

“所以我告诉他我们会修复这个国家。”

在拥有约 333,000 人口的圣克鲁斯省，修理东西曾经是基什内尔一家的职责。

在基什内尔家族的领导下，埃尔卡拉法特修建了一座机场，铺设了通向冰川的道路，并将土地分配给了当地人。在不到 30 年的时间里，人口从不足 7,000 人激增至今年的 30,000 人。

基什内尔主义推动的发展对于 Ana Guerrero 于 20 世纪 60 年代开业的家族巧克力业务至关重要。 “机场带来了游客、投资、大型酒店，随之而来的是更多的顾客，”格雷罗说。

但自今年年初以来，由于央行进口外汇储备不足以及资本管制使得交易变得更加复杂，她的可可供应受到了打击。她连续几周没有找到关键成分。

“我在布宜诺斯艾利斯的供应商从一月份开始向我发送消息，解释为什么我们的产品还没有到达，”格雷罗在她的商店里滚动着手机说道。 “我们已经到了我无法制定计划的地步。”

当地商人丹尼·费尔德曼表示，基什内尔主义在该地区占主导地位。

“但他们创造了一个行不通的模式，现在我们的孩子在这个国家没有未来，”自 1987 年以来一直住在埃尔卡拉法特的费尔德曼说。“现在我投票支持变革。”

露辛达·艾略特报道；亚当·乔丹和丹尼尔·沃利斯编辑; Sat, 21 Oct 2023 14:16:44 GMT GXJUH3MTLVM6JLXMVUX4MZ2MCU https://www.reuters.com/world/americas/argentinas-icy-south-political-dynasty-fades-new-power-rises-2023-10-21/Lucinda Elliott阿根廷选举/圣克鲁斯（更新 1，PIX） Zelenskiy discusses Middle East, Ukraine peace formula in call with Turkey's Erdogan- statement

泽连斯基表示，乌克兰总统泽连斯基周六与土耳其总统埃尔多安进行了通话，两人讨论了乌克兰的和平方案、粮食安全和中东局势。

泽连斯基在 Telegram 上写道：“我们讨论了下一轮和平方案谈判，该谈判将在马耳他举行。土耳其将参加，并增加其权威声音和立场。”

他补充说：“我们还讨论了中东局势，并一致认为需要确保保护平民和尊重人道法。”

麦克斯·亨德 (Max Hunder) 报道; Sat, 21 Oct 2023 14:16:27 GMT HX7NQSW7QZJTVJRIDLD2PMUMZ4 https://www.reuters.com/world/zelenskiy-discusses-middle-east-ukraine-peace-formula-call-with-turkeys-erdogan-2023-10-21/Reuters乌克兰危机/泽连斯基埃尔多安（紧急） First aid convoy enters Gaza Strip from EgyptSummary:
  • 随着冲突加剧，西奈半岛的援助物资堆积如山
  • 20辆卡车组成的车队包括药品、食品，但没有燃料
  • 战前每天有数百辆卡车进入加沙
  • 联合国称加沙局势“灾难性”

自战争爆发以来，第一支前往被围困的加沙地带的人道主义援助车队于周六通过拉法过境点抵达，此前由于运送救援物资的条件发生争执，车队滞留在埃及。

联合国表示，这支由 20 辆卡车组成的车队包括巴勒斯坦红新月会将接收的救生物资，但这些援助物资只是所需数量的一小部分，目前还不清楚未来几天将允许运送多少援助物资。

拉法是进出不受以色列控制的加沙地带的主要通道，也是为加沙230万居民提供救援的重点。

联合国官员表示，加沙每天至少需要 100 辆卡车来满足紧急需求，任何援助物资的运送都应该持续、大规模。冲突爆发前，平均每天约有 450 辆救援卡车抵达那里。

联合国人道主义事务负责人马丁·格里菲斯在一份声明中表示：“加沙的人道主义局势已经岌岌可危，已经达到了灾难性的程度。”

他说：“我相信，这次交付将成为提供基本物资（包括食品、水、药品和燃料）的可持续努力的开始。”

10月7日，哈马斯对以色列领土发动致命袭击，以色列对加沙实施全面封锁和空袭。拉法过境点此后不久就停止运作，加沙一侧的轰炸损坏了道路和建筑物，需要维修。

物资告罄

联合国警告说，加沙的食物已经耗尽，维持医院备用发电机运行所需的燃料供应已达到危险的低水平。

以色列表示，在哈马斯释放袭击中劫持的人质之前，不会允许任何援助物资从其领土进入，而且只要援助物资不落入哈马斯手中，就可以通过埃及进入。

国际捐助者已将援助物资空运到位于埃及西奈半岛拉法以西约 45 公里（28 英里）处的阿里什。

在之前的加沙冲突期间，埃及没有开展大规模救援工作，当时援助物资是通过以色列控制的凯雷姆沙洛姆过境点。

以色列军方周六表示，进入加沙的援助不包括燃料，只会运往飞地南部地区，以色列敦促平民聚集在那里。

许多加沙居民涌入南部地区，以避免北部的空袭，不过他们也表示，该地区没有任何地方是安全的。

巴勒斯坦红新月会的马哈茂德·阿布·阿塔在进入拉法过境点接收物资时说道：“我们通过增加更多志愿者和汽车，提高了红新月会的后勤和行动能力。我们在汗尤尼斯和拉法租用了仓库。”援助。

联合国秘书长安东尼奥·古特雷斯周五访问边境，推动援助物资进入，他表示，检查以色列要求的援助物资的机制仍在制定中，救援物资的运送不应与释放人质挂钩。或疏散外国人。

当乔·拜登在访问以色列期间会见以色列总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡及其战时内阁时，美国总统向他们保证：“我不认为你必须是犹太人才能成为犹太复国主义者，而我就是犹太复国主义者。”

据一位了解闭门言论的美国官员称，聚集在特拉维夫酒店宴会厅的政界人士和将军们点头表示赞同，尽管以色列轰炸加沙以报复巴勒斯坦哈马斯武装分子的毁灭性袭击和地面入侵迫在眉睫。

具有爱尔兰天主教血统的拜登过去曾用类似的措辞来表达他对以色列的喜爱。但此前从未报道过的这一时刻表明，拜登几十年来作为美国政坛主要的“以色列之友”之一，似乎在指导他度过总统任期的一场决定性危机。

这也突显了他面临的挑战，既要坚定不移地支持以色列，又要说服内塔尼亚胡——他与内塔尼亚胡有着悠久的历史——避免加剧加沙平民死亡人数和人道主义灾难，并使进一步释放美国人质变得更加复杂。

“拜登与以色列的联系深深植根于他的政治基因中，”曾在民主党和共和党政府中担任过六位国务卿的前中东谈判代表亚伦·戴维·米勒 (Aaron David Miller) 说。 “无论他喜欢与否，他都处于必须应对的危机之中。”

路透社采访了十几位现任和前任助手、议员和分析人士，其中一些人表示，拜登目前在战时对内塔尼亚胡的支持可能会让美国有影响力来试图缓和以色列在加沙的反应。

据另一位熟悉谈判情况的美国官员透露，在周三与助手的私人会谈中，两位领导人没有表现出会谈中有时出现的紧张气氛。

但拜登确实就即将到来的攻势向内塔尼亚胡提出了尖锐的问题，包括“你有没有想过后天和后天会发生什么？”这位官员说。美国和地区消息人士对誓言摧毁哈马斯的以色列是否尚未制定最终方案表示怀疑。

拜登在寻求 2024 年连任时，与这位右翼领导人的结盟可能会疏远民主党内的一些进步人士，国际社会对以色列策略的强烈抗议也将一些责任归咎于美国

这也促使许多巴勒斯坦人和阿拉伯世界的其他人认为拜登过于偏袒以色列，无法充当公正的和平调解人。

数十年锻造而成

拜登将自己亲以色列的世界观部分归功于他的父亲，他的父亲在第二次世界大战和纳粹大屠杀之后坚称，毫无疑问，1948 年将以色列建立为犹太人家园的正义性。

拜登对几个世纪以来犹太人遭受的迫害的认识以及去年美国反犹太事件数量创历史新高也可能有助于解释为什么哈马斯在 10 月 7 日袭击以色列中犯下的暴行在 80 年来如此令人不安。据一位前美国官员称，是一位老总统。

拜登于 1973 年进入国家政坛，在接下来的 50 年里，他在担任美国参议员、巴拉克·奥巴马 (Barack Obama) 的副总统以及最后的总统期间，坚定了自己的政策立场 — — 坚决支持以色列的安全，并支持巴勒斯坦建国的步骤。

他的职业生涯以深入参与以色列-阿拉伯冲突为标志，其中包括与以色列总理果尔达·梅厄 (Golda Meir) 的一次经常被提及的会面，梅厄在 1973 年赎罪日战争前夕告诉这位年轻的议员，以色列的秘密武器是“我们没有立足之地”。不然就走吧。”

根据 Open Secrets 数据库，拜登在参议院任职 36 年，是参议院历史上接受亲以色列团体捐款最多的人，收到了 420 万美元。

作为副总统，拜登经常调解奥巴马和内塔尼亚胡之间的紧张关系。

奥巴马第一任期内的中东顾问丹尼斯·罗斯回忆说，拜登进行干预是为了防止内塔尼亚胡因2010年访问期间外交冷落而受到报复。罗斯说，奥巴马本来想对以色列宣布在东耶路撒冷大规模扩建犹太人住房一事采取严厉措施，东耶路撒冷是该市在 1967 年战争中被占领的半个城市，其中大部分是阿拉伯人。

“每当与以色列的事态失控时，拜登就是桥梁，”现供职于华盛顿近东政策研究所的罗斯说。 “他对以色列的承诺是如此强烈……这就是我们现在看到的本能。”

尽管拜登和内塔尼亚胡自称是长期朋友，但近几个月来，随着白宫回应以色列反对内塔尼亚胡限制以色列最高法院权力的计划，他们的关系出现了紧张。

渐进的异议

两国现在发现自己处于一个不稳定的联盟，可能会受到以色列地面进攻的考验。

美国共和党参议员林赛·格雷厄姆在接受路透社采访时表示，相信拜登和内塔尼亚胡关系中的“时间之弧”将使他们能够合作。

但曾担任拜登参议院同事多年的格雷厄姆含蓄地表示，他“必须”设定“红线”，以防止哈马斯的恩人伊朗卷入冲突。

拜登警告伊朗不要介入，但没有说明后果。

哈马斯武装分子在以色列城镇肆虐，造成 1,400 人死亡，并劫持了约 200 名人质，其中包括美国人。此后，以色列对加沙进行了围困。加沙官员称，至少 4,385 名巴勒斯坦人被杀。

尽管共和党人几乎一致支持以色列采取的任何行动，但拜登面临着推动以色列克制和停火的进步派派系的反对。

国会中唯一的巴勒斯坦裔美国人众议员拉什达·特莱布 (Rashida Tlaib) 对支持者说：“拜登总统，并非所有美国人都在这件事上支持你，你需要醒来并理解。” “我们实际上正在看着人们实施种族灭绝。”

但专家表示，拜登可能会在与他一样热爱以色列的独立选民中赢得支持。

周一公布的路透社/益普索民意调查显示，美国公众对以色列的同情比过去更加强烈，共和党人对以色列的支持率最高，为 54%，而民主党人的支持率为 37%。与年长的美国人相比，年轻的美国人对以色列的支持较少。

面临低支持率的拜登和一些民主党同僚预计也会警惕与美国主要亲以色列游说团体 AIPAC（美国选举中的强大力量）发生冲突。

但这场危机也引发了对拜登没有对巴勒斯坦人的困境给予足够关注的批评，在以色列占领下，巴勒斯坦人建国的希望变得越来越渺茫。

美国官员曾表示，现在还不是恢复长期搁置的巴以谈判的时机，主要是因为双方都顽固不化。

前巴勒斯坦谈判顾问哈立德·埃尔金迪表示：“政府对这一问题的忽视是造成我们今天处境的一个关键因素。”

现供职于华盛顿中东研究所的埃尔金迪表示，拜登对以色列袭击加沙的“空白支票”“粉碎了美国所剩无几的信誉，这也许是不可逆转的”。

Argentine voters are sharply divided ahead of a historic and uncertain presidential election on Sunday, with some saying they might not make up their mind until they reach the ballot box, opening up the potential for last minute drama.

The vote is a tight three-way race between frontrunner radical outsider Javier Milei, ruling Peronist Economy Minister Sergio Massa and center-right former security minister Patricia Bullrich, all offering starkly different visions for Argentina.

"I will vote for whomever seems the least bad. But I tell you I'm 50-50 until Sunday," said Soledad Sanchez, a public accountant in Buenos Aires, adding that she was oscillating between the two main opposition candidates Bullrich and Milei.

"Let's see what vote I put in the envelope."

Libertarian economist Milei is in pole position to win, though would likely face a second round. Polls suggest Massa is ahead of Bullrich to claim the second run-off spot, though pollsters failed to predict the result of an August open primary, leaving plenty of room for doubt.

The vote marks a major crossroads for Argentina, one of the world's top grains exporters, the largest debtor by far to the International Monetary Fund (IMF), and which has large troves of shale oil and gas, as well as electric battery metal lithium.

Yamila Papina, a public sector worker in the capital, said she was backing the current center-left government's candidate Massa, adding she was worried about proposals by Milei to cut the size of the state and sharply reduce spending.

"In that system the divides are going to be increasingly wide. ... I don't want that model at all," she said. "There's no debate who I will vote for in these elections. It will be Sergio Massa."

Bullrich, whose support has been diluted by the abrupt rise of far-right rival Milei, is the conservative establishment candidate and backed by many in the local business world, who like her strong and stable message as well as security focus.

"Bullrich is the most rational, which means proposing change that is a little more, perhaps, expected and reasonable," said Hernan Etchaleco, director of a local communications consultancy firm. "That's what I would want for the country."

Milei, however, has been the talk of the campaign since posting a shock win in the August primary and leading most of the recent polls. He has clicked with voters, especially the young, angry at years of economic malaise that is sharpening now with inflation at 138% and two-fifths of people in poverty.

"I have lived my entire life with issues going on," said Agustin Geist, 24, who was born just before the last major economic crisis in 2001-2002, the shadow of which still looms over Argentina today.

"It seems to me that it is time for change, to see how we can alter the reality of the country."

  • Arab leaders demand end to decades-long cycle of violence
  • Urge renewed effort to reach Israeli-Palestinian peace
  • Abbas says Palestinians will not leave their land
  • France urges aid corridor into Gaza

Arab leaders at a Cairo summit condemned Israeli bombardment of Gaza as Europeans said civilians should be shielded, but the absence of Israel and senior US officials at the meeting undermined any prospect for halting an escalating war.

Leaders and foreign ministers were meeting as a two-week conflict in neighbouring Gaza raged on, amid growing concern in many countries at an unfolding humanitarian catastrophe in the blockaded enclave that is home to 2.3 million people.

Arab states said it was time to restart efforts to end a decades-long cycle of violence between Israelis and Palestinians, which flared once again on Oct. 7 when Palestinian group Hamas launched a deadly assault on Israeli soil and Israel responded with a devastating counteroffensive on Gaza.

The United States, Israel's closest ally and a vital player in all past peace efforts in the region, only sent the charge d'affaires of its Cairo embassy and Israel was entirely absent. Diplomats said a joint summit declaration was unlikely.

Jordan's King Abdullah denounced what he termed global silence about Israel's attacks, which have killed thousands in Hamas-ruled Gaza and made over a million homeless, and urged an even-handed approach to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

"The message the Arab world is hearing is that Palestinian lives matter less than Israeli ones," he said, adding he was outraged and grieved by acts of violence waged against innocent civilians in Gaza, the Israeli-occupied West Bank, and Israel.

Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas said Palestinians would not be displaced or driven off their land.

"We won't leave, we won't leave," he told the summit.

Israel has vowed to wipe the Iranian-backed Hamas militant group "off the face of the earth" over a shock Oct. 7 assault on southern Israel that killed 1,400 people, the deadliest Palestinian militant attack in Israel's 75-year history.

It has said it told Palestinians to move south within Gaza for their own safety, although the coastal strip is only 45 km (28 miles) long and Israeli air strikes have also hit the south.

French Foreign Minister Catherine Colonna told the summit a humanitarian corridor was needed to deliver aid to civilians, which she said could lead to a ceasefire.

Germany said Israel's fight against Hamas must be carried out with due concern for the humanitarian situation in Gaza and Britain urged the Israeli military to respect international law and show restraint.

CEASEFIRE

The meeting was looking into ways to head off a wider regional war. But three diplomats said it was unlikely there would be a joint statement because of sensitivities around any calls for a ceasefire, and whether to include mention of Hamas's attack and Israel's right to defend itself.

Hamas' backer Iran did not attend the summit.

The absence of some Western leaders has cooled expectations. German Chancellor Olaf Scholz, British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak and French President Emmanuel Macron did not attend.

The summit comes as Israel prepares for a ground assault on Gaza with more than 4,100 Palestinians killed so far.

Arab states fear the offensive could drive Gaza residents permanently from their homes and even into neighbouring states - as happened when Palestinians fled or were forced from their homes in the 1948 war following Israel's creation.

Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi said his country opposed what he called the displacement of Palestinians into Egypt's largely desert Sinai region, adding the only solution was an independent Palestinian state.

Egypt fears insecurity near the border with Gaza in northeastern Sinai, where it faced an Islamist insurgency that peaked after 2013 and has now largely been suppressed.

Jordan, home to many Palestinian refugees and their descendants, fears a wider conflagration would give Israel the chance to expel Palestinians en masse from the West Bank.

King Abdullah said forced displacement "is a war crime according to international law, and a red line for all of us."

Shortly before the summit opening, trucks loaded with humanitarian aid began entering the Rafah crossing into Gaza. Egypt has been trying for days to channel humanitarian relief to Gaza through the crossing, the one access point not controlled by Israel.

Slovenia on Saturday deployed police on border crossings with Croatia and Hungary to prevent potential security threats, leading to queues as travellers waited to have their documents checked.

The Slovenian government had on Friday decided to introduce temporary border controls until Oct. 30, following its neighbour Italy which introduced controls on its border crossing with Slovenia to improve home security.

Police were deployed on 14 border crossings with Croatia and Hungary, Slovenian news agency STA reported. The remaining 18 crossings will not have a permanent police presence.

Travellers queued to have their papers checked at the Obrezje crossing on the border with Croatia, where checks had not taken place since Jan. 1 this year when Croatia joined the control-free Schengen Area.

Katica Fjacko, who was travelling from the Croatian capital Zagreb, said she had left earlier to make the journey because of the controls. "Now this is a bigger chaos, people are worried", she said.

Explaining its decision to introduce border controls, the government cited security threats that may come from what it said were "members of various terrorist and extremist movements and groups" moving from areas of armed conflict and aiming to reach Europe.

It also cited a rise of organised crime in the western Balkans.

Pakistan's three-time Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif arrived home on Saturday from four years of self-imposed exile in London, aiming to kick start his party's campaign for next year's election and targeting former premier Imran Khan as the biggest rival.

The 73-year-old veteran politician returned to his eastern hometown of Lahore, where he will lead a rally hours after his chartered plane landed in Islamabad carrying more than 150 people from his party and media organisations, the party and sources said.

Local TV news channels showed Sharif disembarking from a helicopter at a helipad close to the Minar-e-Pakistan monument where thousands of his supporters were waiting for his address.

During a brief stay in the Islamabad airport lounge he signed and filed appeals against the convictions he was jailed for before he left the country in 2019.

"The process to sign and verify legal documents have been completed," close aide Ishaq Dar posted on X, formerly known as Twitter.

Rallies from various regions of the South Asian country were pouring into Lahore ahead of his arrival, a party spokesperson said. Heavy police contingents were deployed to guard the rally's venue, said police officer Ali Nasir Rizvi.

Sharif had not set foot in Pakistan since leaving for London in 2019 to receive medical treatment while serving a 14-year prison sentence for corruption. His convictions remain in force, but a court on Thursday barred authorities from arresting him until Tuesday, when he is to appear in court.

While he cannot run for or hold public office because of his convictions, his legal team says he plans to appeal and his party says he aims to become prime minister for a fourth time.

Sharif's biggest challenge will be to wrestle back his support base from his main rival, Khan, who despite being in jail remains popular following his ouster from the premiership in 2022.

Khan, too, is disqualified from the election because of his August graft conviction, which he has appealed.

ECONOMIC GROWTH

Nuclear-armed Pakistan, a nation of 241 million people, is experiencing the impact of an economic crisis that has worsened during the 16-month rule of Nawaz Sharif's younger brother, Shehbaz Sharif, who led a coalition government after Khan's removal.

老谢里夫有着追求经济增长和发展的记录。 When he was removed as premier in 2017, Pakistan's growth rate was 5.8% and inflation was around 4%. In September, inflation was more than 31% year-on-year and growth is projected to be less than 2% this financial year.

"It is very sad to see that things have deteriorated so badly," Sharif said before boarding the plane in comments telecast by local TV channels.

Rising living costs have imposed severe pressures on many Pakistanis after the younger Sharif's coalition government had to agree to harsh fiscal adjustments to resume funding from International Monetary Fund (IMF), which had suspended payments after Khan scuttled a deal in his last days in office.

纳瓦兹·谢里夫表示，在与巴基斯坦政治中发挥着巨大作用的高级将领发生争执后，他在强大军方的要求下被赶出了政府。

他说，军方随后在 2018 年大选中支持汗。汗和军方否认这一点。

The military and Khan fell out in 2022, and over the last few months they have been involved in a bruising showdown , which has afforded Sharif some political space.

军方否认干涉政治。

"An evergreen rule about Pakistani politics is that your chances of taking power are always greater when you're in the good books of the army," said Michael Kugelman, director of the South Asia Institute at the Wilson Center.

“在他漫长的政治生涯中，谢里夫与军方高层的关系忽冷忽热。现在处于相对友好的阶段，他将在政治上受益。”

  • Children showing symptoms of trauma, psychiatrists say
  • Most Gaza residents scarred by previous wars with Israel
  • Little prospect in besieged enclave for respite soon

Gaza's children are showing ever more signs of trauma two weeks into Israel's intense bombardment , parents and psychiatrists in the tiny, crowded enclave say, with no safe place to hide from the falling bombs and little prospect of respite.

Children make up about half of Gaza's 2.3 million population, living under near constant bombardment with many packed into temporary shelters in UN-run schools after fleeing their homes with little food or clean water.

Israel is expected to launch a ground attack on Gaza shortly in response to a cross-border assault by Hamas fighters on southern Israel on Oct. 7 that killed more than 1,400 people, with a further 210 taken hostage.

"Children ... have started to develop serious trauma symptoms such as convulsions, bed-wetting, fear, aggressive behaviour, nervousness, and not leaving their parents' sides," said Gaza psychiatrist Fadel Abu Heen.

More than 4,100 Palestinians have been killed in Gaza so far, including more than 1,500 children, while 13,000 people have been injured according to the Palestinian health ministry.

Conditions in makeshift shelters in United Nations schools, where more than 380,000 people are camped out in hope of escaping the bombardment, only compound the problem.

There are sometimes 100 people sleeping in each classroom, which all require continuous cleaning. There is little electricity and water so bathrooms and toilets are very dirty.

"Our children suffer a lot at night. They cry all night, they pee themselves without meaning to and I don't have time to clean up after them, one after the other," said Tahreer Tabash, a mother of six children sheltering in a school.

Even there, they are not safe. Such schools have been hit several times, the United Nations has said, and Tabash has seen strikes hitting nearby buildings. When her children hear so much as a chair being moved, they jump in fear, she said.

"That lack of any safe place has created a general sense of fear and horror among the entire population and children are most impacted," said Abu Heen.

"Some of them reacted directly and expressed their fears. Although they may need immediate intervention, they may be in a better state than the other kids who kept the horror and trauma inside them," he said.

MENTAL TOLL

One house in Khan Younis, in the south of the enclave, is sheltering about 90 people including 30 under the age of 18, where they have to sleep in shifts for lack of space.

"When there's an explosion or any target getting hit nearby they are always screaming, always frightened. We try to calm the younger ones, try telling them, 'Don't worry, it's just fireworks'. But the older ones understand what's going on," said Ibrahim al-Agha, an engineer sheltering in the house.

"They will need a lot of support mentally after this war finishes," Agha said.

However, Gaza's healthcare system was already over-stretched before this month's war, which has pushed it to the brink of collapse, and mental health experts have long warned of the terrible toll that was already being exacted on children.

A 2022 report by aid group Save the Children found the psychosocial wellbeing of children in Gaza at "alarmingly low levels" after 11 days of fighting in 2021, leaving half of all Gaza children in need of support.

Mental health experts in Gaza have said there is no such thing there as post traumatic stress disorder because the trauma in the enclave is continuous, with repeated bouts of armed conflict stretching back nearly two decades.

Early on Saturday, after an Israeli air strike destroyed a building in Gaza City, killing many of the Abo Akr family, a large group of children stood among those watching rescuers picking through the rubble for survivors and bodies.

As women nearby wailed and wept, the children stood watching, their faces showing nothing.

  • 最新进展：
  • First aid trucks enter Gaza 12 days into 'total siege' by Israel
  • Start rolling towards distribution hubs in south Gaza
  • Heavy overnight Israeli bombardment in parts of Gaza
  • 50 people killed when aircraft bomb homes -Palestinians

Trucks carrying aid crossed into southern Gaza on Saturday, the first convoy of humanitarian supplies since Israel began a devastating siege 12 days ago and after further heavy Israeli bombardment overnight that killed dozens of Palestinians.

US President Joe Biden had said this week that agreement had been reached for 20 aid trucks to cross through Gaza's Rafah border point with Egypt, and added on Friday he believed those first trucks would pass through within 48 hours.

Witnesses said aid trucks exited the crossing after checks and proceeded into Gaza's southern area including the major towns of Rafah and Khan Younis where hundreds of thousands of people displaced by Israel's unrelenting air war are sheltering.

However, Palestinian officials were disappointed that fuel supplies were not included and added that the aid was only three percent of what used to get into Gaza before the crisis.

"Excluding the fuel from the humanitarian aid means the lives of patients and injured will remain at risk. Gaza hospitals are running out of the basic requirements to pursue medical interventions," the Gaza health ministry said.

Israel's "total siege" of Gaza after the Oct. 7 cross-border attack on southern Israel by militants of the Islamist movement Hamas has left Gaza's 2.3 million people running out of food, water, medicines and fuel.

The United Nations said the convoy included life-saving supplies that would be received and distributed by the Palestinian Red Crescent, with Hamas' consent. Israel has warned that no aid should end up in Hamas hands.

"The humanitarian situation in Gaza – already precarious – has reached catastrophic levels," UN humanitarian chief Martin Griffiths said in a statement.

"I am confident that this delivery will be the start of a sustainable effort to provide essential supplies – including food, water, medicine and fuel."

UN officials say at least 100 trucks daily are needed and that any aid operation must be sustainable at scale - a tall order now with Israel carrying out devastating bombardments of the enclave day and night.

Before the outbreak of conflict, an average of about 450 aid trucks were arriving daily in Gaza.

FIRST TWO HOSTAGES RELEASED

Israel kept up heavy bombardment of targets throughout Gaza in Saturday's early hours after Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu vowed to "fight until victory" following the release of the first two hostages by Hamas.

Hamas on Friday freed Americans Judith Tai Raanan, 59, and her daughter Natalie, 17, who were among around 210 kidnapped in the assault on southern Israel by Hamas this month. Hamas said it acted in part "for humanitarian reasons" in response to Qatari mediation.

Hamas gunmen seized the hostages when they burst out of the blockaded enclave into Israel and killed 1,400 people, mainly civilians, in a shock rampage, the deadliest single attack on Israelis since the country's founding 75 years ago.

Gaza's Health Ministry said on Saturday Israel's air and missile strikes had killed at least 4,385 Palestinians, including hundreds of children, while over a million of the besieged territory's people have been displaced.

Israel has amassed tanks and troops near the fenced border around the small coastal enclave for a planned ground invasion with the objective of annihilating Hamas, after several inconclusive wars dating to its seizure of power there in 2007.

OVERNIGHT ATTACKS

Overnight Israeli fighter jets struck a "large number of Hamas terror targets throughout" Gaza including command centres and combat positions inside multi-storey buildings, the military said in a statement.

Gaza's health ministry and Hamas media said Israeli aircraft had overnight targeted several family houses across Gaza, one of the world's most densely populated places, killing at least 50 people and injuring dozens.

Hamas said it fired rockets towards Israeli's biggest city Tel Aviv on Saturday in response to those deaths.以色列军方报告称，黎明前，加沙又向以色列南部边境社区发射了新一轮火箭弹。 There was no immediate word of any casualties.

Terrified Palestinians who were forced to evacuate their homes after Israel's deadly overnight bombings lashed out at the reports of aid trucks about to enter Gaza, saying it was a ceasefire and not food that they needed.

"They were asleep when the missile was dropped on them, innocent children, their father, their grandfather, what did they do? Did they fire rockets? Carried bullets? They are innocent children who did nothing!" cried one tearful woman.

"We have been fighting and the Arab nations are just watching. Canned food, is that the price of the Palestinian people who are offering sacrifices everywhere?"

Most of Gaza's inhabitants depend on humanitarian aid. The heavily urbanised coastal strip has been under Israeli and Egyptian blockade since Hamas seized control of it after Israeli ended a 38-year occupation.

Israel has told all civilians to evacuate the northern half of the Gaza Strip, which includes Gaza City. Many people have yet to leave saying they fear losing everything and have nowhere safe to go given that southern areas have also been bombarded.

The United Nations humanitarian affairs office said more than 140,000 homes - nearly a third of all homes in Gaza - had been damaged, with nearly 13,000 completely destroyed.

'CAIRO PEACE SUMMIT'

Diplomacy to secure a ceasefire has been fruitless so far.

Egypt held a summit on the Gaza crisis on Saturday to try to head off a wider regional war but assembled Middle Eastern and European leaders were expected to struggle to agree a common position on the Israel-Hamas conflagration.

Arab leaders at the summit condemned Israel's two-week-old bombardment of Gaza and demanded renewed efforts to reach a Middle East peace settlement to end a decades-long cycle of violence between Israelis and Palestinians.

Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas said Palestinians would not be displaced or driven off their land. "We won't leave, we won't leave," he told the summit.

The United States, Israel's closest ally and a vital player in all past efforts towards Middle East peace, only sent the charge d'affaires of its embassy in Cairo. Israel was absent, as were several other major Western leaders, cooling expectations for what the hastily-convened event could achieve.

Russia's foreign ministry said on Saturday it had summoned the Czech Republic's temporary charge d'affaires in Russia, protesting against Prague's response to an air strike on Hroza in northeastern Ukraine this month that killed dozens.

The ministry said it had summoned the Czech diplomat on Oct. 17 "in response to the recent demarche by the Czech foreign ministry".

Writing by Alexander Marrow; editing by Mark Heinrich and Toby Chopra ; Sat, 21 Oct 2023 13:33:36 GMT PVL7MAPSIJPJ5BACAUSF2RIRFM https://www.reuters.com/world/europe/russia-summoned-czech-charge-daffaires-over-response-hroza-attack-2023-10-21/Reuters乌克兰CRISIS/RUSSIA CZECH REPUBLIC (UPDATE 1) EU envoy tells Kosovo and Serbia to return to dialogue

The European Union Special Envoy Miroslav Lajcak urged Serbia and Kosovo to return to dialogue on normalising ties to avoid a repeat of last month's violence in northern Kosovo.

Tensions between Belgrade and Pristina have run high since Sept. 24, when around 30 armed Serbs stormed the village of Banjska in Kosovo's predominantly Serb north and barricaded themselves into a Serbian Orthodox monastery.

Police recaptured the monastery after a shootout in which three attackers and a Kosovo police officer were killed.

"The attacks in Banjska have changed many things and they need to be properly investigated...At the same time the dialogue must continue," Lajcak said after meeting Kosovo Prime Minister Albin Kurti.

"If there is not dialogue there might be a repetition of escalation."

Last month's gunbattle prompted new international concern over stability in Kosovo, which has an ethnic Albanian majority and declared independence from Serbia in 2008 after a guerrilla uprising and a 1999 NATO intervention.

Lajcak is visiting the region with the United States Special Envoy for the Western Balkans, Gabriel Escobar, and representatives of France, Germany and Italy.

After discussions with Kurti, the group will travel to meet Serbian President Aleksandar Vucic later on Saturday.

Some 50,000 Serbs who live in north Kosovo do not recognise Pristina's institutions and see Belgrade as their capital. They have often clashed with Kosovo police and international peacekeepers, but last month's violence was the worst in years.

Lajcak urged Pristina to start working on establishing an association of Serb municipalities to allow greater autonomy for Serb majority areas. Kurti has rejected the proposal, arguing that autonomy could lead to the secession of the Serb-majority area and its unification with Serbia.

Pristina authorities have accused Belgrade of arming and supporting the Serb fighters in Banjska, something Serbian authorities have denied.

Lajcak urged Belgrade to investigate the events and punish any perpetrators in its territory.

Serbia refuses to recognise independence of Kosovo and considers it still part of its territory.

The United States and Britain on Friday urged New Delhi not to insist Canada reduce its diplomatic presence in India and expressed concern after Ottawa pulled out 41 diplomats amid a dispute over the murder of a Sikh separatist.

Canada has alleged Indian involvement in the June murder in a Vancouver suburb of Canadian citizen and Sikh separatist leader Hardeep Singh Nijjar , whom India called a "terrorist." India denies the allegation.

"We are concerned by the departure of Canadian diplomats from India, in response to the Indian government's demand of Canada to significantly reduce its diplomatic presence in India," US State Department spokesperson Matthew Miller said.

Washington has said it took Canada's allegations seriously and, along with London, urged India to cooperate with Canada in the murder probe even as Western powers have been reluctant to openly condemn India.

Analysts say the US and the UK do not want to damage ties with India , which they view as a counterbalance to their main Asian rival China.

But Friday's statements from the US State Department and Britain's Foreign Office have been the most direct criticism by Washington and London of New Delhi thus far in this case.

"We do not agree with the decisions taken by the Indian government that have resulted in a number of Canadian diplomats departing India," a spokesperson for Britain's Foreign Office said.

Canada withdrew 41 diplomats from India after New Delhi last month asked Ottawa to reduce its diplomatic presence following Canada's allegations over Nijjar's killing. Canada on Friday said it was temporarily suspending in-person operations at consulates in several Indian cities and warned of visa processing delays.

"Resolving differences requires diplomats on the ground. We have urged the Indian government not to insist upon a reduction in Canada's diplomatic presence and to cooperate in the ongoing Canadian investigation," the US State Department said, adding that it expects "India to uphold its obligations under the 1961 Vienna Convention on Diplomatic Relations."

Britain's Foreign Office also cited the Vienna Convention. It said "the unilateral removal of the privileges and immunities that provide for the safety and security of diplomats is not consistent with the principles or the effective functioning of the Vienna Convention."

  • 印度尼西亚、马来西亚和印度举行规模较小的示威活动
  • 集会要求停止对加沙的猛烈轰炸
  • 哈马斯袭击造成 1,400 人死亡后，以色列发起行动

星期五，从雅加达到突尼斯的抗议者要求以色列停止对加沙的轰炸，此前近两周的猛烈空袭和炮击已造成 4,100 人死亡。

以色列正在准备在这片拥挤的巴勒斯坦飞地发动一场地面战争，旨在消灭哈马斯。哈马斯是一个激进的伊斯兰组织，于 10 月 7 日闯入以色列城镇，造成 1,400 人死亡并劫持人质。

虽然一些西方政府表示支持以色列的军事行动，但许多穆斯林国家呼吁立即停火，许多国家的人民对加沙的状况感到愤怒，并表达了对巴勒斯坦人的声援。

周二晚间，加沙当局称一家医院发生爆炸，造成数百人死亡，该地区大部分地区突然爆发抗议活动。哈马斯称，以色列空袭造成了此次事件。以色列指责巴勒斯坦组织发射火箭失败。

In Jordan, which made peace with Israel in 1994, but where much of the population has Palestinian heritage, more than 6,000 protesters marched in the centre of the capital while thousands more rallied near the Israeli embassy.

抗议者表达了对哈马斯的支持，敦促其用火箭弹袭击和自杀式爆炸袭击以色列，并向巴勒斯坦组织高喊：“我们是你们的军队。”

数千名示威者还聚集在土耳其和埃及这两个长期以来与以色列建立全面外交关系的国家，要求停止轰炸。

大约2000人聚集在伊斯坦布尔的贝亚泽特清真寺前，焚烧以色列总理本杰明·内塔尼亚胡的肖像，并挥舞巴勒斯坦国旗。一些人举着标语牌，上面写着：“停止种族灭绝”和“恐怖主义以色列”。

在埃及，数千名抗议者站在世界上最古老的清真寺之一的爱资哈尔清真寺前，高呼“阿拉伯军队在哪里？”，而其他人则聚集在中央解放广场。

一些人要求对以色列采取军事行动，另一些人则表示阿拉伯国家应该考虑使用其他方法来阻止对加沙的轰炸。埃及与加沙接壤，但未能通过谈判开放其过境点以允许援助进入。

“巴勒斯坦是唯一团结我们声音的国家。如果海湾国家不提供援助，至少他们应该停止输送石油和天然气。这是他们至少应该做的，”开罗的抗议者穆罕默德·戈马说。

燃烧的旗帜和雕像

在摩洛哥，政府同意于 2020 年与以色列实现关系正常化，以换取美国承认摩洛哥对西撒哈拉有争议领土的主权，伊斯兰主义者和左派人士表示，他们将在周五晚些时候举行静坐。

Hundreds of people marched in central Tunis, a smaller protest than ones that have rallied there against Israel's Gaza campaign in recent days. Others demonstrated in front of the US embassy.

"The real terrorism is Israel and America, which supports it," said Souhail Ben Nasser, a protester in the Tunis crowd.

In southeast Asia hundreds of people gathered to protest near the US embassies in each of the Indonesian and Malaysian capitals, burning Israeli flags and stamping on pictures of Netanyahu and US President Joe Biden.

"Today we gather here with the same intention to condemn the criminal act by Israel," said Qilla Marisa, a protester in Kuala Lumpur.

Muslims in India staged smaller protests in Jaipur and Mumbai, holding up placards reading "Free Palestine".

Israel's biggest regional foe Iran, and allied groups around the region, also held state-sanctioned protests. In Iraq, Shi'ite militias backed by Tehran mobilised hundreds of supporters in Baghdad near the bridge leading to the fortified Green Zone where the US embassy is located.

On Iraq 's border with Jordan, hundreds of supporters of Iran-backed paramilitary groups staged a sit-in to voice support for Gaza, brought in by bus. "We are going to support our people in Palestine," said one of them, 26-year-old Hussein Samir.
